title: Changes With the Big Ten’s Offense
text:
Headline: Big Ten Teams Are Running More Plays Per Game After the NCAA’s Clock Rule Change
The NCAA’s 2024 rule change to keep the clock running after first downs was designed to speed up games. To see whether that actually reduced the number of offensive plays, I compared the average number of plays per game for each Big Ten team across the 2024-25 and 2025-26 seasons.
First I loaded the tidyverse package and imported game-by-game statistics for the 2024 and 2025 college football seasons from two CSV files.


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
season24 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv")


Rows: 1717 Columns: 79
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
season25 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv")


Rows: 711 Columns: 77
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Conferenc...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


To focus the analysis on the Big Ten, I created a list of all 18 current conference teams. Then, I filtered the 2024 and 2025 season data to include only games played by Big Ten teams.


Code
big_ten_teams <- c("Oregon", "Indiana", "Penn State", "Ohio State", "Illinois", "Iowa",  "Michigan",  "Minnesota", "Rutgers", "USC", "Washington", "Nebraska", "Michigan State", "UCLA", "Wisconsin", "Northwestern","Maryland", "Purdue")

season24 %>%
  filter(Team %in% big_ten_teams)


# A tibble: 235 × 79
      Rk   Gtm Date       Location Opponent       Result Points PointsOpp OT   
   <dbl> <dbl> <date>     <chr>    <chr>          <chr>   <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>
 1     1     1 2024-08-31 <NA>     Idaho          W          24        14 <NA> 
 2     2     2 2024-09-07 <NA>     Boise State    W          37        34 <NA> 
 3     3     3 2024-09-14 @        Oregon State   W          49        14 <NA> 
 4     4     4 2024-09-28 @        UCLA           W          34        13 <NA> 
 5     5     5 2024-10-04 <NA>     Michigan State W          31        10 <NA> 
 6     6     6 2024-10-12 <NA>     Ohio State     W          32        31 <NA> 
 7     7     7 2024-10-18 @        Purdue         W          35         0 <NA> 
 8     8     8 2024-10-26 <NA>     Illinois       W          38         9 <NA> 
 9     9     9 2024-11-02 @        Michigan       W          38        17 <NA> 
10    10    10 2024-11-09 <NA>     Maryland       W          39        18 <NA> 
# ℹ 225 more rows
# ℹ 70 more variables: PassCmp <dbl>, PassAtt <dbl>, PassPct <dbl>,
#   PassYds <dbl>, PassTD <dbl>, PassYA <dbl>, PassAYA <dbl>, PassRate <dbl>,
#   RushAtt <dbl>, RushYds <dbl>, RushYA <dbl>, RushTD <dbl>, TotalPlays <dbl>,
#   TotalYds <dbl>, TotalAvg <dbl>, FGA <dbl>, FGM <dbl>, XPA <dbl>, XPM <dbl>,
#   Punt <dbl>, PuntYds <dbl>, FirstDownPass <dbl>, FirstDownRush <dbl>,
#   FirstDownPen <dbl>, FirstDown <dbl>, Penalties <dbl>, PenaltyYds <dbl>, …


Code
season25 %>%
  filter(Team %in% big_ten_teams)


# A tibble: 91 × 77
      Rk   Gtm Date       Location Opponent       Result Points PointsOpp OT   
   <dbl> <dbl> <date>     <chr>    <chr>          <chr>   <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>
 1     1     1 2025-08-30 <NA>     Old Dominion   W          27        14 <NA> 
 2     2     2 2025-09-06 <NA>     Kennesaw State W          56         9 <NA> 
 3     3     3 2025-09-12 <NA>     Indiana St.    W          73         0 <NA> 
 4     4     4 2025-09-20 <NA>     Illinois       W          63        10 <NA> 
 5     5     5 2025-09-27 @        Iowa           W          20        15 <NA> 
 6     1     1 2025-08-30 <NA>     Texas          W          14         7 <NA> 
 7     2     2 2025-09-06 <NA>     Grambling      W          70         0 <NA> 
 8     3     3 2025-09-13 <NA>     Ohio           W          37         9 <NA> 
 9     4     4 2025-09-27 @        Washington     W          24         6 <NA> 
10     5     5 2025-10-04 <NA>     Minnesota      W          42         3 <NA> 
# ℹ 81 more rows
# ℹ 68 more variables: PassCmp <dbl>, PassAtt <dbl>, PassPct <dbl>,
#   PassYds <dbl>, PassTD <dbl>, PassYA <dbl>, PassAYA <dbl>, PassRate <dbl>,
#   RushAtt <dbl>, RushYds <dbl>, RushYA <dbl>, RushTD <dbl>, TotalPlays <dbl>,
#   TotalYds <dbl>, TotalAvg <dbl>, FGA <dbl>, FGM <dbl>, XPA <dbl>, XPM <dbl>,
#   Punt <dbl>, PuntYds <dbl>, FirstDownPass <dbl>, FirstDownRush <dbl>,
#   FirstDownPen <dbl>, FirstDown <dbl>, Penalties <dbl>, PenaltyYds <dbl>, …


Next, I calculated the average number of offensive plays per game for each Big Ten team in both the 2024 and 2025 seasons. This involved grouping the filtered data by team and taking the mean of the total plays, while making sure to ignore any missing values.


Code
avg_plays_24 <- season24 %>% 
  filter(Team %in% big_ten_teams) %>%
  group_by(Team) %>%
  summarise(avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays, na.rm = TRUE))

avg_plays_25 <- season25 %>%
  filter(Team %in% big_ten_teams) %>%
  group_by(Team) %>%
  summarise(avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays, na.rm = TRUE))


In this step, I created a horizontal bar chart to show the average number of offensive plays per game for each Big Ten team in the 2024 and 2025 seasons. By reordering the teams based on their average plays, I made it easier to compare teams at a glance. Flipping the coordinates with coord_flip() helped keep team names readable, especially with a long list of 18 teams. I also applied a clean theme and added axis labels and a title to make the chart easier to interpret. Overall, this visualization gives a clear snapshot of offensive tempo across the conference in both seasons.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data = avg_plays_24, 
    aes(x = reorder(Team, avg_plays),
        weight = avg_plays),
    fill = "steelblue") + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Big Ten Teams’ Average Offensive Plays Per Game (2024 Season)",
    x = "Team", 
    y = "Average Plays") + 
  theme_light() + 
  coord_flip()











Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data = avg_plays_25, 
    aes(x = reorder(Team, avg_plays),
        weight = avg_plays),
    fill = "steelblue") + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::comma) + 
  labs(
    title = "Big Ten Teams’ Average Offensive Plays Per Game (2025 Season)",
    x = "Team", 
    y = "Average Plays") + 
  theme_light() + 
  coord_flip()









Big Ten teams are running slightly more offensive plays on average in the 2025 season compared to 2024, indicating a modest increase in tempo across the conference. Several teams have seen significant changes in their rankings for average plays per game. Most notably, Purdue jumped from last place in 2024 to third in 2025, while Indiana climbed from ninth to second, and Rutgers moved into the top spot after finishing second the previous year. On the other hand, Maryland, which led the conference in 2024, dropped to fifth, and Ohio State fell from 14th to last place. Other teams like USC, Penn State, and Wisconsin also dropped in the rankings, while Nebraska and Oregon remained consistently near the top. Overall, the data suggests a shift in offensive strategies for some programs, with a few accelerating their pace of play while others have slowed down.

title: Welcome To My Blog

This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!
